segment.source: Animations overview
segment.target: Animations overview

segment.source: Use the animations from the Windows Runtime animation library to integrate the Windows look and feel into your app.
segment.target: Use the animations from the Windows Runtime animation library to integrate the Windows look and feel into your app.

segment.source: Animations overview
segment.target: Animations overview

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Animations in the Windows Runtime can enhance your app by adding movement and interactivity.
segment.target: Animations in the Windows Runtime can enhance your app by adding movement and interactivity.

segment.source: By using the animations from the Windows Runtime animation library, you can integrate the Windows look and feel into your app.
segment.target: By using the animations from the Windows Runtime animation library, you can integrate the Windows look and feel into your app.

segment.source: This topic provides a summary of the animations and examples of typical scenarios where each is used.
segment.target: This topic provides a summary of the animations and examples of typical scenarios where each is used.

segment.source: Tip The Windows Runtime controls for XAML include certain types of animations as built-in behaviors that come from an animation library.
segment.target: Tip The Windows Runtime controls for XAML include certain types of animations as built-in behaviors that come from an animation library.

segment.source: By using these controls in your app, you can get the animated look and feel without having to program it yourself.
segment.target: By using these controls in your app, you can get the animated look and feel without having to program it yourself.

segment.source: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library provide these benefits:
segment.target: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library provide these benefits:

segment.source: Motions that align to the Guidelines for animations
segment.target: Motions that align to the Guidelines for animations

segment.source: Fast, fluid transitions between UI states that inform but do not distract the user
segment.target: Fast, fluid transitions between UI states that inform but do not distract the user

segment.source: Visual behavior that indicates transitions within an app to the user
segment.target: Visual behavior that indicates transitions within an app to the user

segment.source: For example, when the user adds an item to a list, instead of the new item instantly appearing in the list, the new item animates into place.
segment.target: For example, when the user adds an item to a list, instead of the new item instantly appearing in the list, the new item animates into place.

segment.source: The other items in the list animate to their new positions over a short period of time, making room for the added item.
segment.target: The other items in the list animate to their new positions over a short period of time, making room for the added item.

segment.source: The transition behavior here makes the control interaction more apparent to the user.
segment.target: The transition behavior here makes the control interaction more apparent to the user.

segment.source: The animation library does not provide animations for every possible scenario.
segment.target: The animation library does not provide animations for every possible scenario.

segment.source: There are cases where you might wish to create a custom animation in XAML.
segment.target: There are cases where you might wish to create a custom animation in XAML.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: Types of animations
segment.target: Types of animations

segment.source: The Windows Runtime animation system and the animation library serve the larger goal of enabling controls and other parts of UI to have an animated behavior.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime animation system and the animation library serve the larger goal of enabling controls and other parts of UI to have an animated behavior.

segment.source: There are several distinct types of animations.
segment.target: There are several distinct types of animations.

segment.source: Theme transitions are applied automatically when certain conditions change in the UI, involving controls or elements from the predefined Windows Runtime XAML UI types.
segment.target: Theme transitions are applied automatically when certain conditions change in the UI, involving controls or elements from the predefined Windows Runtime XAML UI types.

segment.source: These are termed theme transitions because the animations support the Windows look and feel, and define what all apps do for particular UI scenarios when they change from one interaction mode to another.
segment.target: These are termed theme transitions because the animations support the Windows look and feel, and define what all apps do for particular UI scenarios when they change from one interaction mode to another.

segment.source: The theme transitions are part of the animation library.
segment.target: The theme transitions are part of the animation library.

segment.source: Theme animations are animations to one or more properties of predefined Windows Runtime XAML UI types.
segment.target: Theme animations are animations to one or more properties of predefined Windows Runtime XAML UI types.

segment.source: Theme animations differ from theme transitions because theme animations target one specific element and exist in specific visual states within a control, whereas the theme transitions are assigned to properties of the control that exist outside of the visual states and influence the transitions between those states.
segment.target: Theme animations differ from theme transitions because theme animations target one specific element and exist in specific visual states within a control, whereas the theme transitions are assigned to properties of the control that exist outside of the visual states and influence the transitions between those states.

segment.source: Many of the Windows Runtime XAML controls include theme animations within storyboards that are part of their control template, with the animations triggered by visual states.
segment.target: Many of the Windows Runtime XAML controls include theme animations within storyboards that are part of their control template, with the animations triggered by visual states.

segment.source: So long as you're not modifying the templates, you'll have those built-in theme animations available for the controls in your UI.
segment.target: So long as you're not modifying the templates, you'll have those built-in theme animations available for the controls in your UI.

segment.source: However, if you do replace templates, then you'll be removing the built-in control theme animations too.
segment.target: However, if you do replace templates, then you'll be removing the built-in control theme animations too.

segment.source: To get them back, you must define a storyboard that includes theme animations within the control's set of visual states.
segment.target: To get them back, you must define a storyboard that includes theme animations within the control's set of visual states.

segment.source: You can also run theme animations from storyboards that aren't within visual states and start them with the Begin method, but that's less common.
segment.target: You can also run theme animations from storyboards that aren't within visual states and start them with the Begin method, but that's less common.

segment.source: Theme animations are part of the animation library.
segment.target: Theme animations are part of the animation library.

segment.source: Visual transitions are applied when a control transitions from one of its defined visual states to another state.
segment.target: Visual transitions are applied when a control transitions from one of its defined visual states to another state.

segment.source: These are custom animations that you write, and are typically related to the custom template you write for a control and the visual state definitions within that template.
segment.target: These are custom animations that you write, and are typically related to the custom template you write for a control and the visual state definitions within that template.

segment.source: The animation only runs during the time between states, and that's typically a short amount of time, a few seconds at most.
segment.target: The animation only runs during the time between states, and that's typically a short amount of time, a few seconds at most.

segment.source: For more info, see "VisualTransition" section of Storyboarded animations for visual states.
segment.target: For more info, see "VisualTransition" section of Storyboarded animations for visual states.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations are applied when they are specifically started by your app code, or by code that comes with a component like a control that you've included.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations are applied when they are specifically started by your app code, or by code that comes with a component like a control that you've included.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations can change the value of any Windows Runtime dependency property over time.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations can change the value of any Windows Runtime dependency property over time.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations aren't limited to UI scenarios; in fact it might be useful to think of them as a state machine technique, if you're familiar with that concept.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations aren't limited to UI scenarios; in fact it might be useful to think of them as a state machine technique, if you're familiar with that concept.

segment.source: A storyboarded animation is not limited to the transition time between visual states; it could be run at any time regardless of a control state change, and the animation can potentially run continuously.
segment.target: A storyboarded animation is not limited to the transition time between visual states; it could be run at any time regardless of a control state change, and the animation can potentially run continuously.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: For more info about dependency properties and where they exist, see Dependency properties overview.
segment.target: For more info about dependency properties and where they exist, see Dependency properties overview.

segment.source: Animations available in the library
segment.target: Animations available in the library

segment.source: The following animations are supplied in the animation library.
segment.target: The following animations are supplied in the animation library.

segment.source: Click on the name of an animation to learn more about their main usage scenarios, how to define them, and to see an example of the animation.
segment.target: Click on the name of an animation to learn more about their main usage scenarios, how to define them, and to see an example of the animation.

segment.source: Content and entrance transition: Animates one piece or set of content into or out of view.
segment.target: Content and entrance transition: Animates one piece or set of content into or out of view.

segment.source: Fade in/out, and crossfade: Shows transient elements or controls, or refreshes a content area.
segment.target: Fade in/out, and crossfade: Shows transient elements or controls, or refreshes a content area.

segment.source: Pointer up/down: Gives visual feedback of a tap or click on a tile.
segment.target: Pointer up/down: Gives visual feedback of a tap or click on a tile.

segment.source: Reposition: Moves an element into a new position.
segment.target: Reposition: Moves an element into a new position.

segment.source: Show/hide popup: Displays contextual UI on top of the view.
segment.target: Show/hide popup: Displays contextual UI on top of the view.

segment.source: Show/hide edge UI: Slides edge-based UI, including large UI such as a panel, into or out of view.
segment.target: Show/hide edge UI: Slides edge-based UI, including large UI such as a panel, into or out of view.

segment.source: List item changes: Adds or deletes an item from a list, or reordering of the items.
segment.target: List item changes: Adds or deletes an item from a list, or reordering of the items.

segment.source: Drag/drop: Gives visual feedback during a drag-and-drop operation.
segment.target: Drag/drop: Gives visual feedback during a drag-and-drop operation.

segment.source: Swipe gestures: Hints that a tile supports the swipe interaction, or indicates swipe-selected state
segment.target: Swipe gestures: Hints that a tile supports the swipe interaction, or indicates swipe-selected state

segment.source: Content transition and entrance transition
segment.target: Content transition and entrance transition

segment.source: Use content transition animations (ContentThemeTransition) to move a piece or a set of content into or out of the current view.
segment.target: Use content transition animations (ContentThemeTransition) to move a piece or a set of content into or out of the current view.

segment.source: For example, the content transition animations show content that was not ready to display when the page was first loaded, or when the content changes on a section of a page.
segment.target: For example, the content transition animations show content that was not ready to display when the page was first loaded, or when the content changes on a section of a page.

segment.source: The XAML animation library doesn't have a concept of an animation that applies to the entire page when the page is loaded, but it does have a separate transition (EntranceThemeTransition) that can apply to content when the page containing the content is first loaded and that part of content is rendered.
segment.target: The XAML animation library doesn't have a concept of an animation that applies to the entire page when the page is loaded, but it does have a separate transition (EntranceThemeTransition) that can apply to content when the page containing the content is first loaded and that part of content is rendered.

segment.source: Thus the first appearance of content can offer different feedback than a change to content does.
segment.target: Thus the first appearance of content can offer different feedback than a change to content does.

segment.source: Fade in/out, and crossfade
segment.target: Fade in/out, and crossfade

segment.source: Use fade in and fade out animations to show or hide transient UI or controls.
segment.target: Use fade in and fade out animations to show or hide transient UI or controls.

segment.source: In XAML these are represented as FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation.
segment.target: In XAML these are represented as FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation.

segment.source: One example is in an app bar in which new controls can appear due to user interaction.
segment.target: One example is in an app bar in which new controls can appear due to user interaction.

segment.source: Another example is a transient scroll bar or panning indicator that is faded out after no user input has been detected for some amount of time.
segment.target: Another example is a transient scroll bar or panning indicator that is faded out after no user input has been detected for some amount of time.

segment.source: Apps should also use the fade in animation when they transition from a placeholder item to the final item as content loads dynamically.
segment.target: Apps should also use the fade in animation when they transition from a placeholder item to the final item as content loads dynamically.

segment.source: Use a crossfade animation to smooth the transition when an item's state is changing; for example, when the app refreshes the current contents of a view.
segment.target: Use a crossfade animation to smooth the transition when an item's state is changing; for example, when the app refreshes the current contents of a view.

segment.source: The XAML animation library does not supply a dedicated crossfade animation (no equivalent for crossFade), but you can achieve the same result using FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation with overlapped timing.
segment.target: The XAML animation library does not supply a dedicated crossfade animation (no equivalent for crossFade), but you can achieve the same result using FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation with overlapped timing.

segment.source: Pointer up/down
segment.target: Pointer up/down

segment.source: Use the PointerUpThemeAnimation and PointerDownThemeAnimation animations to give the user feedback for a successful tap or click on a tile.
segment.target: Use the PointerUpThemeAnimation and PointerDownThemeAnimation animations to give the user feedback for a successful tap or click on a tile.

segment.source: For example, when a user clicks or taps down on a tile, the pointer down animation is played.
segment.target: For example, when a user clicks or taps down on a tile, the pointer down animation is played.

segment.source: Once the click or tap has been released, the pointer up animation is played.
segment.target: Once the click or tap has been released, the pointer up animation is played.

segment.source: Reposition
segment.target: Reposition

segment.source: Use the reposition animations (RepositionThemeAnimation or RepositionThemeTransition) to move an element into a new position.
segment.target: Use the reposition animations (RepositionThemeAnimation or RepositionThemeTransition) to move an element into a new position.

segment.source: For example, moving the headers in a headerd items control uses the reposition animation.
segment.target: For example, moving the headers in a headerd items control uses the reposition animation.

segment.source: Show/hide popup
segment.target: Show/hide popup

segment.source: Use the PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation when you show and hide a Popup or similar contextual UI on top of the current view.
segment.target: Use the PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation when you show and hide a Popup or similar contextual UI on top of the current view.

segment.source: PopupThemeTransition is a theme transition that's useful feedback if you want to light dismiss a popup.
segment.target: PopupThemeTransition is a theme transition that's useful feedback if you want to light dismiss a popup.

segment.source: Show/hide edge UI
segment.target: Show/hide edge UI

segment.source: Use the EdgeUIThemeTransition animation to slide small, edge-based UI into and out of view.
segment.target: Use the EdgeUIThemeTransition animation to slide small, edge-based UI into and out of view.

segment.source: For example, use these animations when you show a custom app bar at the top or bottom of the screen or a UI surface for errors and warnings at the top of the screen.
segment.target: For example, use these animations when you show a custom app bar at the top or bottom of the screen or a UI surface for errors and warnings at the top of the screen.

segment.source: Use the PaneThemeTransition animation to show and hide a pane or panel.
segment.target: Use the PaneThemeTransition animation to show and hide a pane or panel.

segment.source: This is for large edge-based UI such as a custom keyboard or a task pane.
segment.target: This is for large edge-based UI such as a custom keyboard or a task pane.

segment.source: List item changes
segment.target: List item changes

segment.source: Use the AddDeleteThemeTransition animation to add animated behavior when you add or delete an item in an existing list.
segment.target: Use the AddDeleteThemeTransition animation to add animated behavior when you add or delete an item in an existing list.

segment.source: For add, the transition will first reposition existing items in the list to make space for the new items, and then add the new items.
segment.target: For add, the transition will first reposition existing items in the list to make space for the new items, and then add the new items.

segment.source: For delete, the transition removes items from a list and, if necessary, repositions the remaining list items once the deleted items have been removed.
segment.target: For delete, the transition removes items from a list and, if necessary, repositions the remaining list items once the deleted items have been removed.

segment.source: There's also a separate ReorderThemeTransition that you apply if an item changes position in a list.
segment.target: There's also a separate ReorderThemeTransition that you apply if an item changes position in a list.

segment.source: This is animated differently than deleting an item and adding it in a new place with the associated delete/add animations.
segment.target: This is animated differently than deleting an item and adding it in a new place with the associated delete/add animations.

segment.source: Drag/drop
segment.target: Drag/drop

segment.source: Use the drag animations (DragItemThemeAnimation, DragOverThemeAnimation) and drop animation (DropTargetItemThemeAnimation) to give visual feedback when the user drags or drops an item.
segment.target: Use the drag animations (DragItemThemeAnimation, DragOverThemeAnimation) and drop animation (DropTargetItemThemeAnimation) to give visual feedback when the user drags or drops an item.

segment.source: When active, the animations show the user that the list can be rearranged around a dropped item.
segment.target: When active, the animations show the user that the list can be rearranged around a dropped item.

segment.source: It is helpful for users to know where the item will be placed in a list if it is dropped at the current location.
segment.target: It is helpful for users to know where the item will be placed in a list if it is dropped at the current location.

segment.source: The animations give visual feedback that an item being dragged can be dropped between two other items in the list and that those items will move out of the way.
segment.target: The animations give visual feedback that an item being dragged can be dropped between two other items in the list and that those items will move out of the way.

segment.source: Swipe gestures
segment.target: Swipe gestures

segment.source: Use the SwipeHintThemeAnimation animation to show that a tile supports the swipe interaction.
segment.target: Use the SwipeHintThemeAnimation animation to show that a tile supports the swipe interaction.

segment.source: Users can swipe downwards to select a tile.
segment.target: Users can swipe downwards to select a tile.

segment.source: If a user does not know if they can swipe on a tile, a press and hold gesture on the tile will play the swipe hint animation to suggest that the user should interact with the tile through a swipe.
segment.target: If a user does not know if they can swipe on a tile, a press and hold gesture on the tile will play the swipe hint animation to suggest that the user should interact with the tile through a swipe.

segment.source: Use the SwipeBackThemeAnimation animation to show that the tile has been selected, and to return the tile to its rest location.
segment.target: Use the SwipeBackThemeAnimation animation to show that the tile has been selected, and to return the tile to its rest location.

segment.source: Using animations with custom controls
segment.target: Using animations with custom controls

segment.source: The following table summarizes our recommendations for which animation you should use when you create a custom version of these Windows Runtime controls:
segment.target: The following table summarizes our recommendations for which animation you should use when you create a custom version of these Windows Runtime controls:

segment.target: UI type

segment.target: Recommended animation

segment.target: Dialog box

segment.target: FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation

segment.target: Flyout

segment.source: PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: Tooltip
segment.target: Tooltip

segment.source: FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: Context menu
segment.target: Context menu

segment.source: PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: PopInThemeAnimation and PopOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: Command bar
segment.target: Command bar

segment.source: EdgeUIThemeTransition
segment.target: EdgeUIThemeTransition

segment.source: Task pane or edge-based panel
segment.target: Task pane or edge-based panel

segment.source: PaneThemeTransition
segment.target: PaneThemeTransition

segment.source: Contents of any UI container
segment.target: Contents of any UI container

segment.source: ContentThemeTransition
segment.target: ContentThemeTransition

segment.source: For controls or if no other animation applies
segment.target: For controls or if no other animation applies

segment.source: FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: FadeInThemeAnimation and FadeOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: Transition animation examples
segment.target: Transition animation examples

segment.source: Ideally, your app uses animations to enhance the user interface or to make it more attractive without annoying your users.
segment.target: Ideally, your app uses animations to enhance the user interface or to make it more attractive without annoying your users.

segment.source: One way you can do this is to apply animated transitions to UI so that when something enters or leaves the screen or otherwise changes, the animation draws the attention of the user to the change.
segment.target: One way you can do this is to apply animated transitions to UI so that when something enters or leaves the screen or otherwise changes, the animation draws the attention of the user to the change.

segment.source: For example, your buttons may rapidly fade in and out of view rather than just appear and disappear.
segment.target: For example, your buttons may rapidly fade in and out of view rather than just appear and disappear.

segment.source: We created a number of APIs that can be used to create recommended or typical animation transitions that are consistent.
segment.target: We created a number of APIs that can be used to create recommended or typical animation transitions that are consistent.

segment.source: The example here shows how to apply an animation to a button so that it swiftly slides into view.
segment.target: The example here shows how to apply an animation to a button so that it swiftly slides into view.

segment.source: In this code, we add the EntranceThemeTransition object to the transition collection of the button.
segment.target: In this code, we add the EntranceThemeTransition object to the transition collection of the button.

segment.source: Now, when the button is first rendered, it swiftly slides into view rather than just appear.
segment.target: Now, when the button is first rendered, it swiftly slides into view rather than just appear.

segment.source: You can set a few properties on the animation object in order to adjust how far it slides and from what direction, but it's really meant to be a simple API for a specific scenario, that is, to make an eye-catching entrance.
segment.target: You can set a few properties on the animation object in order to adjust how far it slides and from what direction, but it's really meant to be a simple API for a specific scenario, that is, to make an eye-catching entrance.

segment.source: You can also define transition animation themes in the style resources of your app, allowing you to apply the effect uniformly.
segment.target: You can also define transition animation themes in the style resources of your app, allowing you to apply the effect uniformly.

segment.source: This example is equivalent to the previous one, only it is applied using a Style:
segment.target: This example is equivalent to the previous one, only it is applied using a Style:

segment.source: The previous examples apply a theme transition to an individual control, however, theme transitions are even more interesting when you apply them to a container of objects.
segment.target: The previous examples apply a theme transition to an individual control, however, theme transitions are even more interesting when you apply them to a container of objects.

segment.source: When you do this, all the child objects of the container take part in the transition.
segment.target: When you do this, all the child objects of the container take part in the transition.

segment.source: In the following example, an EntranceThemeTransition is applied to a Grid of rectangles.
segment.target: In the following example, an EntranceThemeTransition is applied to a Grid of rectangles.

segment.source: The child rectangles of the Grid transition into view one after the other in a visually pleasing way rather than all at once as would be the case if you applied this animation to the rectangles individually.
segment.target: The child rectangles of the Grid transition into view one after the other in a visually pleasing way rather than all at once as would be the case if you applied this animation to the rectangles individually.

segment.source: Here's a video that demonstrates this animation:
segment.target: Here's a video that demonstrates this animation:

segment.source: Animation showing child rectangle transitioning into view
segment.target: Animation showing child rectangle transitioning into view

segment.source: Child objects of a container can also re-flow when one or more of those children change position.
segment.target: Child objects of a container can also re-flow when one or more of those children change position.

segment.source: In the following example, we apply a RepositionThemeTransition to a grid of rectangles.
segment.target: In the following example, we apply a RepositionThemeTransition to a grid of rectangles.

segment.source: When you remove one of the rectangles, all the other rectangles re-flow into their new position.
segment.target: When you remove one of the rectangles, all the other rectangles re-flow into their new position.

segment.source: This video demonstrates the animation that runs for the rectangles being removed:
segment.target: This video demonstrates the animation that runs for the rectangles being removed:

segment.source: You can apply multiple transition animations to a single object or object container.
segment.target: You can apply multiple transition animations to a single object or object container.

segment.source: For example, if you want the list of rectangles to animate into view and also animate when they change position, you can apply the RepositionThemeTransition and EntranceThemeTransition like this:
segment.target: For example, if you want the list of rectangles to animate into view and also animate when they change position, you can apply the RepositionThemeTransition and EntranceThemeTransition like this:

segment.source: There are several transition effects to create animations on your UI elements as they are added, removed, reordered, and so on.
segment.target: There are several transition effects to create animations on your UI elements as they are added, removed, reordered, and so on.

segment.source: The names of these APIs all contain "ThemeTransition":
segment.target: The names of these APIs all contain "ThemeTransition":

segment.source: API
segment.target: API

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: AddDeleteThemeTransition
segment.target: AddDeleteThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls add or delete children or content.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls add or delete children or content.

segment.source: Typically the control is an item container.
segment.target: Typically the control is an item container.

segment.source: ContentThemeTransition
segment.target: ContentThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for when the content of a control is changing.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for when the content of a control is changing.

segment.source: You can apply this in addition to AddDeleteThemeTransition.
segment.target: You can apply this in addition to AddDeleteThemeTransition.

segment.source: EdgeUIThemeTransition
segment.target: EdgeUIThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for a (small) edge UI transition.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for a (small) edge UI transition.

segment.source: EntranceThemeTransition
segment.target: EntranceThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls first appear.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls first appear.

segment.source: PaneThemeTransition
segment.target: PaneThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for a panel (large edge UI) UI transition.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for a panel (large edge UI) UI transition.

segment.source: PopupThemeTransition
segment.target: PopupThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior that applies to pop-in components of controls (for example, tooltip-like UI on an object) as they appear.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior that applies to pop-in components of controls (for example, tooltip-like UI on an object) as they appear.

segment.source: ReorderThemeTransition
segment.target: ReorderThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for when list-view controls items change order.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for when list-view controls items change order.

segment.source: Typically this happens as a result of a drag-drop operation.
segment.target: Typically this happens as a result of a drag-drop operation.

segment.source: Different controls and themes can have varying characteristics for the animations.
segment.target: Different controls and themes can have varying characteristics for the animations.

segment.source: RepositionThemeTransition
segment.target: RepositionThemeTransition

segment.source: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls change position.
segment.target: Provides the animated transition behavior for when controls change position.

segment.source: Theme animation examples
segment.target: Theme animation examples

segment.source: Transition animations are simple to apply.
segment.target: Transition animations are simple to apply.

segment.source: But you may want to have a bit more control over the timing and order of your animation effects.
segment.target: But you may want to have a bit more control over the timing and order of your animation effects.

segment.source: You can use theme animations to enable more control while still using a consistent theme for how your animation behaves.
segment.target: You can use theme animations to enable more control while still using a consistent theme for how your animation behaves.

segment.source: Theme animations also require less markup than custom animations.
segment.target: Theme animations also require less markup than custom animations.

segment.source: Here, we use the FadeOutThemeAnimation to make a rectangle fade out of view.
segment.target: Here, we use the FadeOutThemeAnimation to make a rectangle fade out of view.

segment.source: Unlike transition animations, a theme animation doesn't have a built-in trigger (the transition) that runs it automatically.
segment.target: Unlike transition animations, a theme animation doesn't have a built-in trigger (the transition) that runs it automatically.

segment.source: You must use a Storyboard to contain a theme animation when you define it in XAML.
segment.target: You must use a Storyboard to contain a theme animation when you define it in XAML.

segment.source: You can also change the default behavior of the animation.
segment.target: You can also change the default behavior of the animation.

segment.source: For example, you can slow down the fade-out by increasing the Duration time value on the FadeOutThemeAnimation.
segment.target: For example, you can slow down the fade-out by increasing the Duration time value on the FadeOutThemeAnimation.

segment.source: Note For purposes of showing basic animation techniques, we're using app code to start the animation by calling methods of Storyboard.
segment.target: Note For purposes of showing basic animation techniques, we're using app code to start the animation by calling methods of Storyboard.

segment.source: You can control how the Storyboard animations run using the Begin, Stop, Pause, and Resume Storyboard methods.
segment.target: You can control how the Storyboard animations run using the Begin, Stop, Pause, and Resume Storyboard methods.

segment.source: However, that's not typically how you include library animations in apps.
segment.target: However, that's not typically how you include library animations in apps.

segment.source: Rather, you usually integrate the library animations into the XAML styles and templates applied to controls or elements.
segment.target: Rather, you usually integrate the library animations into the XAML styles and templates applied to controls or elements.

segment.source: Learning about templates and visual states is a little more involved.
segment.target: Learning about templates and visual states is a little more involved.

segment.source: But we do cover how you'd use library animations in visual states as part of the Storyboarded animations for visual states topic.
segment.target: But we do cover how you'd use library animations in visual states as part of the Storyboarded animations for visual states topic.

segment.source: You can apply several other theme animations to your UI elements to create animation effects.
segment.target: You can apply several other theme animations to your UI elements to create animation effects.

segment.source: The names of these API all contain "ThemeAnimation":
segment.target: The names of these API all contain "ThemeAnimation":

segment.source: API
segment.target: API

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: DragItemThemeAnimation
segment.target: DragItemThemeAnimation

segment.source: Represents the preconfigured animation that applies to item elements being dragged.
segment.target: Represents the preconfigured animation that applies to item elements being dragged.

segment.source: DragOverThemeAnimation
segment.target: DragOverThemeAnimation

segment.source: Represents the preconfigured animation that applies to the elements underneath an element being dragged.
segment.target: Represents the preconfigured animation that applies to the elements underneath an element being dragged.

segment.source: DropTargetItemThemeAnimation
segment.target: DropTargetItemThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that applies to potential drop target elements.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that applies to potential drop target elements.

segment.source: FadeInThemeAnimation
segment.target: FadeInThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured opacity animation that applies to controls when they first appear.
segment.target: The preconfigured opacity animation that applies to controls when they first appear.

segment.source: FadeOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: FadeOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured opacity animation that applies to controls when they are removed from UI or hidden.
segment.target: The preconfigured opacity animation that applies to controls when they are removed from UI or hidden.

segment.source: PointerDownThemeAnimation
segment.target: PointerDownThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation for user action that taps or clicks an item or element.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation for user action that taps or clicks an item or element.

segment.source: PointerUpThemeAnimation
segment.target: PointerUpThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation for user action that runs after a user taps down on an item or element and the action is released.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation for user action that runs after a user taps down on an item or element and the action is released.

segment.source: PopInThemeAnimation
segment.target: PopInThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that applies to pop-in components of controls as they appear.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that applies to pop-in components of controls as they appear.

segment.source: This animation combines opacity and translation.
segment.target: This animation combines opacity and translation.

segment.source: PopOutThemeAnimation
segment.target: PopOutThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that applies to pop-in components of controls as they are closed or removed.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that applies to pop-in components of controls as they are closed or removed.

segment.source: This animation combines opacity and translation.
segment.target: This animation combines opacity and translation.

segment.source: RepositionThemeAnimation
segment.target: RepositionThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation for an object as it is repositioned.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation for an object as it is repositioned.

segment.source: SplitCloseThemeAnimation
segment.target: SplitCloseThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that conceals a target UI using a split animation.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that conceals a target UI using a split animation.

segment.source: SplitOpenThemeAnimation
segment.target: SplitOpenThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that reveals a target UI using a split animation.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that reveals a target UI using a split animation.

segment.source: SwipeBackThemeAnimation
segment.target: SwipeBackThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that applies to controls when an element slides back into its layout slot after a swipe interaction.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that applies to controls when an element slides back into its layout slot after a swipe interaction.

segment.source: SwipeHintThemeAnimation
segment.target: SwipeHintThemeAnimation

segment.source: The preconfigured animation that indicates that a swipe gesture is now possible.
segment.target: The preconfigured animation that indicates that a swipe gesture is now possible.

segment.source: Create your own animations
segment.target: Create your own animations

segment.source: When theme animations are not enough for your needs, you can create your own animations.
segment.target: When theme animations are not enough for your needs, you can create your own animations.

segment.source: You animate objects by animating one or more of their property values.
segment.target: You animate objects by animating one or more of their property values.

segment.source: For example, you can animate the width of a rectangle, the angle of a RotateTransform, or the color value of a button.
segment.target: For example, you can animate the width of a rectangle, the angle of a RotateTransform, or the color value of a button.

segment.source: We term this type of custom animation a storyboarded animation, to distinguish it from the library animations that the Windows Runtime already provides as a preconfigured animation type.
segment.target: We term this type of custom animation a storyboarded animation, to distinguish it from the library animations that the Windows Runtime already provides as a preconfigured animation type.

segment.source: For storyboarded animations, you use an animation that can change values of a particular type (for example DoubleAnimation to animate a Double) and put that animation within a Storyboard to control it.
segment.target: For storyboarded animations, you use an animation that can change values of a particular type (for example DoubleAnimation to animate a Double) and put that animation within a Storyboard to control it.

segment.source: In order to be animated, the property you are animating must be a dependency property.
segment.target: In order to be animated, the property you are animating must be a dependency property.

segment.source: For more info about dependency properties, see Dependency properties overview.
segment.target: For more info about dependency properties, see Dependency properties overview.

segment.source: For more info on creating custom storyboarded animations, including how to target and control them, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info on creating custom storyboarded animations, including how to target and control them, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: The biggest area of app UI definition in XAML where you'll define custom storyboarded animations is if you are defining visual states for controls in XAML.
segment.target: The biggest area of app UI definition in XAML where you'll define custom storyboarded animations is if you are defining visual states for controls in XAML.

segment.source: You'll be doing this either because you are creating a new control class, or because you are re-templating an existing control that has visual states in its control template.
segment.target: You'll be doing this either because you are creating a new control class, or because you are re-templating an existing control that has visual states in its control template.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.

segment.source: These animations aren't usually transitions over time at all, they happen instantaneously, and are really more of a technique for defining a set of property changes for a state.
segment.target: These animations aren't usually transitions over time at all, they happen instantaneously, and are really more of a technique for defining a set of property changes for a state.

segment.source: They don't necessarily apply a visually animated behavior to a UI, although as you'll see the visual states for controls often include the library animations themselves.
segment.target: They don't necessarily apply a visually animated behavior to a UI, although as you'll see the visual states for controls often include the library animations themselves.

segment.source: In this case the theme animations do apply a change over time, though it's usually a short duration.
segment.target: In this case the theme animations do apply a change over time, though it's usually a short duration.
